Before buying this game, I was somewhat of a sceptic of it's worth. Yet after a mere 9 hours of game-play in,........ my opinion has changed. Even though this game is about 6 years old,.....WOW, what a little gem. The story-line, characters & game-play are formidable to say the least, & it's extremely enjoyable to play, with the character/skill level progression being easy to grasp & understand, & yet not rushed.
Even though I haven't  finished this game yet, I highly recommend it. It's a game that puts quality, over quantity & is highly worth grabbing!

[h1] Thoughts: [ALL POSITIVE] [/h1]

- This is a brilliant game. I used to dislike the idea of it, because it's not like the originals but after finally playing it properly I am in love with it.

- The graphics are beautiful. 

- The story is breathtaking. 

- The combat is decent. I loved being able to open tears and such. 

- Burial at Sea is amazing. it's a good insight into Rapture before ADAM completely took over.

- Clash in the clouds is very fun if you enjoy the combat element of Infinite.

maybe not

It's just fun. A fun action game, which some real nice story to keep me going. When it comes to horror games, I am a complete WUSS, so I missed out on the other Bioshock games. This game not being a horror game at all is a nice treat for someone like me!

In fact, I don't even like most standard action games, either. Don't know how or why this game grabbed me, but I'm glad it did, and I'm glad I played through the entire game.

Feel like I should note that I bought this game first on PS3, and painstakingly played through all of it with a controller. I think I bought it again on steam because there was some big bioshock sale, idk... But it's pretty impressive that this game was good enough to keep me playing through the whole thing despite how uncomfortable I was playing a first-person action game solely on a controller (another weakness of mine).

Pros
Gameplay is fun. Personally i love the sniper rifle.
Graphics hold well for 2019, but dont expect last gen, from a close npc detail is potato-ish
Performance is great too (since its an older title) 
Ending is interesting

Cons
The story at the begining is too fast, and makes no sense. The first two hours for me were like "What thef...?"
The enemies are unbalanced, some (95% of what you will encounter) are too easy and some too annoying - nothing impossible though

Potential Cons
Relys too much on looting around, but its not a neccessity and you could in theory ignore it (makes the game harder though - limited or even no upgrates this way)

If you came here for the game, you can safely ignore the following paragraph, but I hope you can finish reading it. 
First of all I want to say I am a little bit disappointed for this game. The developer was trying to vilify multiple groups of people and it evens up a little bit. But as a Chinese,  I did feel intruded by the Boxer's Rebellion part of the game. It's true that the mob killed many missionaries but they already paid their price, 8 countries seized Beijing (translated as Peking at that time) and had a huge massacre there. And yes, US did send more than 3000 solders and made a great contribution to it. The developers might not well familiar with that part of the history and used iconic racism Chinese characters and was not paying as much tribute as they did with the native Americans. I can kinda accept it since it was in comparison with the wounded knee massacre. However, you cannot just borrow Chinese characters and put them inversely at random places. There was an image of "Tian Xia Wei Gong" ("å¤©ä¸‹ç‚ºå…¬", which means "The world belongs to for all") hanging at the doors of the Boxers' Rebellion museum in the game. You might see it a lot in Chinatown, and that's because it was the most famous quote from Sun Yat-sen, one of the founding fathers of China. It definitely has nothing to do with that rebellion. I have to admit it's almost impossible for most people to relate to that feeling. The closest comparison I can come up with is to imagine how you might feel if a popular game from the other part of the world have "All man are created equal" hanged upside down when it was talking about slave trades in early 18th century. 
Finished the main story in just over 7 hours. Bought the entire franchise a couple of years ago, and started with Bioshock remastered. Spent a couple of hours and gave up. It's been years since people started to tell me how good this game is and how it is one of the best representation of games as arts. After finishing the main story, I must admit, I enjoyed the scenery of Columbia. Even based on today's standards (2019) it's still gorgeous when I maxed out everything in 4k. I love wandering in the zip-lines around the floating city. But only a small proportion of the game was located in the "beautiful" city before everything got blew up and I did got bored when I have to travel long distances across the broken city multiple times. This redundant play seems unnecessary to me. The gameplay and actions are smooth and I can hardly find any flaws. Elizabeth is indeed the best teammate you can ever dream of. Return to the plot, the story has lots of contents, and it did raise a lot philosophical problems. However, most of the questions were not revealed until the very end of the story and it made me feel a little bit uncomfortable. It's like "oh yes you killed the boss, and let's talk about some moral dilemmas and makes you feel bad." Despite all those problems, it's still one of the greatest story rich action game I've ever played.
I'm still recommending this game not because I'm completely satisfied with it, but more like I have to accept how difficult it is to understand a different culture. There are lots of misunderstandings between US and China, and we still have a long way to go.
